article:
'Internet Relay Chat' ('IRC') is a protocol for live interactive Internet text
messaging (chat) or synchronous conferencing. {{cite IETF
| rfc = 1459 sectionname = Introduction section = 1 page = 4 idanchor = ietf
}} It is mainly designed for group communication in discussion forums,
called [[#Channels|channels]], {{cite IETF
| rfc = 1459 sectionname = One-to-many section = 3.2 page = 11 idanchor = ietf
}} but also allows one-to-one communication via private
message {{cite IETF
| rfc = 2810 sectionname = One-To-One Communication section = 5.1 page = 5
| idanchor = ietf
}} as well as chat and data transfer, {{cite web
| url = http://www.irchelp.org/irchelp/rfc/dccspec.html title = A description of
| the DCC protocol accessdate = 2011-04-08 last = Rollo first = Troy publisher =
| irchelp.org
}} including file sharing. {{cite book
| last = Wang first = Wallace title = Steal this File Sharing Book edition = 1st
| date = 2004-10-25 publisher = No Starch Press location = San Francisco,
| California isbn = 1-59327-050-X pages = 6167 chapter = Instant Messaging and
| Online Chat Rooms: Internet Relay Chat (IRC)
}}

IRC was created in 1988. Client software is available for every major operating
system that supports Internet access. {{cite web |title=SAGE IRC
Channel |url=http://www.sage.org/about/irc.html |publisher=Sage - The USENIX
Special Interest Group for Sysadmins |accessdate=18 April 2011}} As of
April 2011, the top 100 IRC networks served more than half a million users at a
time, {{cite web
| url = http://irc.netsplit.de/networks/top100.php title = IRC Networks - Top
| 100 accessdate = 2011-04-08 publisher = irc.netsplit.de
}} with hundreds of thousands of channels operating on a total of roughly 1,500 servers out of roughly 3,200 servers worldwide. {{cite web
| url = http://irc.netsplit.de/servers/summary.php title = IRC Servers - Summary
| accessdate = 2011-04-08 publisher = irc.netsplit.de
}}
